documents.summary: This document introduces Cloudflare for Platforms, providing an overview of its use cases, available starter kits, and core features for building multi-tenant application development platforms.

documents.title: Constellation · Constellation docs
documents.description: Constellation allows you to run fast, low-latency inference tasks on pre-trained machine learning models natively on Cloudflare Workers. It supports some of the most popular machine learning (ML) and AI runtimes and multiple classes of models.
documents.summary: Constellation enables developers to run fast, low-latency machine learning inference tasks natively on Cloudflare Workers using pre-trained or custom models. It supports a variety of AI applications including content generation, image classification, and sentiment analysis.

documents.title: Overview · Cloudflare Containers docs
documents.description: Run code written in any programming language, built for any runtime, as part of apps built on Workers.
documents.summary: This document explains how to deploy and manage serverless containers within Cloudflare Workers to support resource-intensive applications and custom runtimes. It provides an overview of integration methods using Wrangler configuration and the Workers runtime API.

documents.title: Overview · Cloudflare D1 docs
documents.description: D1 is Cloudflare's managed, serverless database with SQLite's SQL semantics, built-in disaster recovery, and Worker and HTTP API access.
documents.summary: This document introduces Cloudflare D1, a serverless SQLite database integrated with Workers and Pages, highlighting its core features like horizontal scaling and point-in-time recovery.

documents.title: Overview · Cloudflare Durable Objects docs
documents.description: Durable Objects provide a building block for stateful applications and distributed systems.
documents.summary: This document introduces Durable Objects as a stateful serverless solution that combines compute with globally consistent storage for building collaborative and real-time applications. It provides an overview of core features including SQLite storage, WebSocket hibernation, and durable alarms.

documents.title: Overview · Cloudflare Email Routing docs
documents.description: Cloudflare Email Routing is designed to simplify the way you create and manage email addresses, without needing to keep an eye on additional mailboxes. With Email Routing, you can create any number of custom email addresses to use in situations where you do not want to share your primary email address, such as when you subscribe to a new service or newsletter. Emails are then routed to your preferred email inbox, without you ever having to expose your primary email address.
documents.summary: This document introduces Cloudflare Email Routing, a service that allows users to create custom email addresses and route incoming mail to a primary inbox for improved privacy and management.

documents.title: Overview · Cloudflare Hyperdrive docs
documents.description: Hyperdrive is a service that accelerates queries you make to existing databases, making it faster to access your data from across the globe from Cloudflare Workers, irrespective of your users' location.
documents.summary: Hyperdrive accelerates database queries from Cloudflare Workers by providing connection pooling and query caching for existing PostgreSQL and MySQL databases.

documents.title: Overview · Cloudflare Images docs
documents.description: Streamline your image infrastructure with Cloudflare Images. Store, transform, and deliver images efficiently using Cloudflare's global network.
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of Cloudflare Images, an end-to-end service for storing, transforming, and optimizing images through a global delivery network.

documents.title: Cloudflare Workers KV · Cloudflare Workers KV docs
documents.description: Workers KV is a data storage that allows you to store and retrieve data globally. With Workers KV, you can build dynamic and performant APIs and websites that support high read volumes with low latency.
documents.summary: This document introduces Workers KV, a global low-latency key-value storage service, explaining how to interact with it via Workers Bindings and the REST API.

documents.title: Overview · Cloudflare MoQ docs
documents.description: MoQ (Media over QUIC) is a protocol for delivering live media content using QUIC transport. It provides efficient, low-latency media streaming by leveraging QUIC's multiplexing and connection management capabilities.
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of Cloudflare's implementation of the Media over QUIC (MoQ) protocol, including current specification support, browser compatibility details, and known technical discrepancies.

documents.title: Overview · Cloudflare Pages docs
documents.description: Deploy your Pages project by connecting to your Git provider, uploading prebuilt assets directly to Pages with Direct Upload or using C3 from the command line.
documents.summary: Cloudflare Pages is a platform for building and deploying full-stack applications globally, offering features like Git integration, serverless functions, and instant rollbacks.

documents.title: Pipelines · Cloudflare Pipelines Docs
documents.description: Cloudflare Pipelines ingests events, transforms them with SQL, and delivers them to R2 as Iceberg tables or as Parquet and JSON files.
documents.summary: This document introduces Cloudflare Pipelines, a service for ingesting, transforming with SQL, and delivering streaming data to R2 storage as Iceberg tables or Parquet files. It outlines the core components of the system including streams, pipelines, and sinks for building managed data warehouses.

documents.title: Overview · Cloudflare Privacy Gateway docs
documents.description: Privacy Gateway is a managed service deployed on Cloudflare’s global network that implements part of the Oblivious HTTP (OHTTP) IETF standard. The goal of Privacy Gateway and Oblivious HTTP is to hide the client's IP address when interacting with an application backend.
documents.summary: Cloudflare Privacy Gateway is a managed service that implements the Oblivious HTTP standard to protect client privacy by masking IP addresses from application backends.

documents.title: Overview · Cloudflare Queues docs
documents.description: Cloudflare Queues integrate with Cloudflare Workers and enable you to build applications that can guarantee delivery, offload work from a request, send data from Worker to Worker, and buffer or batch data.
documents.summary: This document introduces Cloudflare Queues, a service for guaranteed message delivery that integrates with Workers to handle asynchronous tasks, batching, and retries.

documents.title: Overview · Cloudflare R2 docs
documents.description: Cloudflare R2 is a cost-effective, scalable object storage solution for cloud-native apps, web content, and data lakes without egress fees.
documents.summary: Cloudflare R2 is an S3-compatible object storage service that allows users to store large amounts of unstructured data without egress bandwidth fees. The document outlines its primary features, common use cases, and provides links to related tools and resources.

documents.title: R2 SQL · R2 SQL docs
documents.description: A distributed SQL engine for R2 Data Catalog
documents.summary: This document introduces R2 SQL, a serverless distributed query engine designed to perform SQL analytics on Apache Iceberg tables stored in Cloudflare's R2 Data Catalog. It explains how the engine leverages distributed compute and file pruning for efficient data processing and provides information on its open beta status.

documents.title: Overview · Cloudflare Realtime docs
documents.description: RealtimeKit is a set of SDKs and APIs that lets you add customizable live video and voice to web or mobile applications. It is fully customisable and you sets up in just a few lines of code.
documents.summary: This document provides an overview and comparison of Cloudflare Realtime products, including RealtimeKit, Realtime SFU, and TURN services, to help developers select the right tool for building live video and audio applications.

documents.title: Overview · Cloudflare Sandbox SDK docs
documents.description: The Sandbox SDK enables you to run untrusted code securely in isolated environments. Built on Containers, Sandbox SDK provides a simple API for executing commands, managing files, running background processes, and exposing services — all from your Workers applications.
documents.summary: This document introduces the Sandbox SDK for Cloudflare Workers, a tool for executing untrusted code within secure, isolated Linux containers for applications like AI agents and data analysis.

documents.title: Overview · Cloudflare Stream docs
documents.description: Cloudflare Stream lets you or your end users upload, store, encode, and deliver live and on-demand video with one API, without configuring or maintaining infrastructure.
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of Cloudflare Stream, a serverless platform for uploading, encoding, and delivering live and on-demand video content.

documents.title: Overview · Cloudflare Turnstile docs
documents.description: Turnstile can be embedded into any website without sending traffic through Cloudflare and works without showing visitors a CAPTCHA.
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of Cloudflare Turnstile, a smart and non-intrusive CAPTCHA alternative that uses browser-based challenges to verify human traffic.

documents.title: Cloudflare Vectorize
documents.description: title: Overview · Cloudflare Vectorize docs description: Vectorize is a globally distributed vector database that enables you to build full-stack, AI-powered applications with Cloudflare Workers. Vectorize makes querying embeddings — representations of values or objects like text, images, audi...
documents.summary: This document introduces Cloudflare Vectorize, a globally distributed vector database designed for storing and querying machine learning embeddings within the Cloudflare Workers platform.

documents.title: Overview · Cloudflare Workers docs
documents.description: With Cloudflare Workers, you can expect to:
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of Cloudflare Workers, a serverless platform for building and deploying high-performance applications across a global network. It outlines the platform's core features, supported programming languages, and various integration options for storage, compute, and AI services.

documents.title: Overview · Cloudflare Workers VPC
documents.description: Securely connect your private cloud to Cloudflare to build cross-cloud apps.
documents.summary: This document introduces Workers VPC, a feature that allows Cloudflare Workers to securely connect to private APIs and services in external cloud providers or on-premise environments using Cloudflare Tunnel.

documents.title: Overview · Cloudflare Workflows docs
documents.description:
With Workflows, you can build applications that chain together multiple steps, automatically retry failed tasks,
and persist state for minutes, hours, or even weeks - with no infrastructure to manage.
documents.summary: This document introduces Cloudflare Workflows, a tool for building durable multi-step applications on Cloudflare Workers with features like automatic retries, state persistence, and long-running execution.

documents.title: Overview · Cloudflare Zaraz docs
documents.description: Cloudflare Zaraz gives you complete control over third-party tools and services for your website, and allows you to offload them to Cloudflare's edge, improving the speed and security of your website. With Cloudflare Zaraz you can load tools such as analytics tools, advertising pixels and scripts, chatbots, marketing automation tools, and more, in the most optimized way.
documents.summary: This document introduces Cloudflare Zaraz, a service designed to offload third-party tools and scripts to the edge to improve website performance, privacy, and security. It highlights core features such as tool integration, custom managed components, a client-side web API, and consent management.

documents.title: Background · Cloudflare MoQ docs
documents.description: Over the years, efficient delivery of live media content has attracted significant interest from the networking and media streaming community. Many applications, including live streaming platforms, real-time communication systems, gaming, and interactive media experiences, require low-latency media delivery. However, it remained a major challenge to deliver media content in a scalable, efficient, and robust way over the internet. Currently, most solutions rely on proprietary protocols or repurpose existing protocols like HTTP/2 or WebRTC that weren't specifically designed for media streaming use cases.
documents.summary: This document introduces the Media Over QUIC (MoQ) protocol, explaining its development by the IETF to provide a standardized, low-latency solution for live media delivery. It outlines the protocol's key benefits, including efficiency, security, and adaptive streaming capabilities built upon QUIC transport.

documents.title: Functions · Cloudflare Pages docs
documents.description: Pages Functions allows you to build full-stack applications by executing code on the Cloudflare network with Cloudflare Workers. With Functions, you can introduce application aspects such as authenticating, handling form submissions, or working with middleware. Workers runtime features are configurable on Pages Functions, including compatibility with a subset of Node.js APIs and the ability to set a compatibility date or compatibility flag. Use Functions to deploy server-side code to enable dynamic functionality without running a dedicated server.
documents.summary: This document introduces Cloudflare Pages Functions, which allow developers to build full-stack applications by executing server-side code on the Cloudflare network. It covers core features including routing, middleware, and integration with Workers runtime APIs for dynamic functionality.

documents.title: Overview · Cloudflare Realtime docs
documents.description: Cloudflare Realtime SFU is infrastructure for real-time audio/video/data applications. It allows you to build real-time apps without worrying about scaling or regions. It can act as a selective forwarding unit (WebRTC SFU), as a fanout delivery system for broadcasting (WebRTC CDN) or anything in between.
documents.summary: This document introduces Cloudflare Realtime SFU, a serverless infrastructure designed for building and scaling real-time audio, video, and data applications using WebRTC.

documents.title: TURN Service · Cloudflare Realtime docs
documents.description: Separately from the SFU, Realtime offers a managed TURN service. TURN acts as a relay point for traffic between WebRTC clients like the browser and SFUs, particularly in scenarios where direct communication is obstructed by NATs or firewalls. TURN maintains an allocation of public IP addresses and ports for each session, ensuring connectivity even in restrictive network environments.
documents.summary: This document provides technical specifications, connection details, and operational limits for Cloudflare's managed TURN and STUN relay services.

By incorporating human feedback, you can gain deeper insights into how the model's responses are perceived and how well it performs from a user-centric perspective. This feedback can then be used in evaluations to calculate performance metrics, driving optimization and ultimately enhancing the reliability, accuracy, and efficiency of your AI application.
documents.summary: This tutorial explains how to provide human feedback on AI model logs via the Cloudflare dashboard to calculate performance metrics and improve model reliability.

documents.description: Data Loss Prevention (DLP) for AI Gateway helps protect your organization from inadvertent exposure of sensitive data through AI interactions. documents.title: Dynamic routing · Cloudflare AI Gateway docs
documents.description: Dynamic routing enables you to create request routing flows through a visual interface or a JSON-based configuration. Instead of hard-coding a single model, with Dynamic Routing you compose a small flow that evaluates conditions, enforces quotas, and chooses models with fallbacks. You can iterate without touching application code—publish a new route version and you’re done. With dynamic routing, you can easily implement advanced use cases such as:
documents.summary: This document explains how to set up and manage dynamic routing for AI requests, enabling conditional model selection, rate limiting, and A/B testing through a visual or JSON-based interface.

documents.title: How AI Search works · Cloudflare AI Search docs
documents.description: AI Search (formerly AutoRAG) is Cloudflare’s managed search service. You can connect your data such as websites or unstructured content, and it automatically creates a continuously updating index that you can query with natural language in your applications or AI agents.
documents.summary: This document explains the core architecture and processes of Cloudflare AI Search, detailing how the system automates data indexing and handles real-time natural language querying.

documents.title: What is RAG
documents.description: title: What is RAG · Cloudflare AI Search docs description: Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) is a way to use your own data with a large language model (LLM). Instead of relying only on what the model was trained on, RAG searches for relevant information from your data source and uses it to h...
documents.summary: This document explains the fundamentals of Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) and its workflow, describing how it enhances Large Language Models with specific data sources to provide accurate, grounded responses.

documents.title: Similarity cache · Cloudflare AI Search docs
documents.description: Similarity-based caching in AI Search lets you serve responses from Cloudflare’s cache for queries that are similar to previous requests, rather than creating new, unique responses for every request. This speeds up response times and cuts costs by reusing answers for questions that are close in meaning.
documents.summary: This document explains how similarity-based caching in Cloudflare AI Search uses MinHash and LSH to reuse responses for semantically similar queries to improve performance and reduce costs.

documents.title: Chunking · Cloudflare AI Search docs
documents.description: Chunking is the process of splitting large data into smaller segments before embedding them for search. AI Search uses recursive chunking, which breaks your content at natural boundaries (like paragraphs or sentences), and then further splits it if the chunks are too large.
documents.summary: This document explains the concept of recursive chunking in AI Search and how to configure chunk size and overlap to optimize data embedding and retrieval.

documents.title: Data source · Cloudflare AI Search docs
documents.description: AI Search can directly ingest data from the following sources:
documents.summary: This document outlines the supported data ingestion sources for AI Search, specifically detailing how to connect website domains and Cloudflare R2 buckets.

documents.title: Indexing · Cloudflare AI Search docs
documents.description: AI Search automatically indexes your data into vector embeddings optimized for semantic search. Once a data source is connected, indexing runs continuously in the background to keep your knowledge base fresh and queryable.
documents.summary: This document explains the automated and manual indexing processes for AI Search, including job monitoring, management controls, and optimization best practices.

documents.title: Metadata · Cloudflare AI Search docs
documents.description: Use metadata to filter documents before retrieval and provide context to guide AI responses. This page covers how to apply filters and attach optional context metadata to your files.
documents.summary: This document explains how to use metadata filtering and custom context fields to refine search results and guide AI model responses in an AI Search system.

documents.title: Models · Cloudflare AI Search docs
documents.description: AI Search uses models at multiple stages. You can configure which models are used, or let AI Search automatically select a smart default for you.

documents.title: Path filtering · Cloudflare AI Search docs
documents.description: Path filtering allows you to control which files or URLs are indexed by defining include and exclude patterns. Use this to limit indexing to specific content or to skip files you do not want searchable.
documents.summary: This document explains how to use path filtering to control which files or URLs are indexed in AI Search through include and exclude patterns. It details configuration methods, wildcard syntax, and filtering behavior for website and R2 data sources.

documents.title: Query rewriting · Cloudflare AI Search docs
documents.description: Query rewriting is an optional step in the AI Search pipeline that improves retrieval quality by transforming the original user query into a more effective search query.
documents.summary: This document explains how query rewriting uses large language models to transform user input into precise search queries, enhancing retrieval quality in vector-based search systems.

documents.title: Reranking · Cloudflare AI Search docs
documents.description: Reranking can help improve the quality of AI Search results by reordering retrieved documents based on semantic relevance to the user’s query. It applies a secondary model after retrieval to "rerank" the top results before they are outputted.
documents.summary: This document explains how to enable and configure reranking in AI Search to improve the accuracy of retrieved results using semantic relevance models.

documents.title: Retrieval configuration · Cloudflare AI Search docs
documents.description: AI Search allows you to configure how content is retrieved from your vector index and used to generate a final response. Two options control this behavior:
documents.summary: This document explains how to configure retrieval behavior in AI Search using the match threshold and maximum number of results parameters. It details how these settings influence semantic search results and how they can be applied via the API or Workers Binding.

documents.description: A service API token grants AI Search permission to access and configure resources in your Cloudflare account. This token is different from API tokens you use to interact with your AI Search instance.

documents.title: Lifecycle of a Container · Cloudflare Containers docs
documents.description:
After you deploy an application with a Container, your image is uploaded to
Cloudflare's Registry and distributed globally to Cloudflare's Network.
Cloudflare will pre-schedule instances and pre-fetch images across the globe to ensure quick start
times when scaling up the number of concurrent container instances.
documents.summary: This document details the deployment, lifecycle, and request routing mechanisms for Cloudflare Containers, explaining how they interact with Workers and Durable Objects. It covers technical aspects such as rolling deploys, instance placement, cold starts, and container shutdown processes.

documents.title: Image Management · Cloudflare Containers docs
documents.description:
When running wrangler deploy, if you set the image attribute in your Wrangler configuration to a path to a Dockerfile, Wrangler will build your container image locally using Docker, then push it to a registry run by Cloudflare.
This registry is integrated with your Cloudflare account and is backed by R2. All authentication is handled automatically by
Cloudflare both when pushing and pulling images.
documents.summary: This document explains how to build, push, and manage container images for Cloudflare Workers using the Wrangler CLI, including instructions for using Cloudflare's internal registry and Amazon ECR.

documents.title: Limits and Instance Types · Cloudflare Containers docs
documents.description:
The memory, vCPU, and disk space for Containers are set through predefined instance types.
Six instance types are currently available:
documents.summary: This document defines the available instance types and resource limits for Workers Containers, including specifications for vCPU, memory, and disk allocation.

documents.title: Rollouts · Cloudflare Containers docs
documents.description:
When you run wrangler deploy, the Worker code is updated immediately and Container
instances are updated using a rolling deploy strategy. The default rollout configuration is two steps,
where the first step updates 10% of the instances, and the second step updates the remaining 90%.
This can be configured in your Wrangler config file using the rollout_step_percentage property.
documents.summary: This document explains the mechanics of rolling deployments for Cloudflare Worker Containers, detailing rollout percentages, shutdown grace periods, and immediate deployment options.

documents.title: Scaling and Routing · Cloudflare Containers docs
documents.description:
Currently, Containers are only scaled manually by getting containers with a unique ID, then
starting the container. Note that that getting a container does not automatically start it.
documents.summary: This document explains how to scale and manage Cloudflare container instances using manual lifecycle controls, temporary routing helpers, and upcoming native autoscaling features.

documents.title: Import and export data · Cloudflare D1 docs
documents.description: D1 allows you to import existing SQLite tables and their data directly, enabling you to migrate existing data into D1 quickly and easily. This can be useful when migrating applications to use Workers and D1, or when you want to prototype a schema locally before importing it to your D1 database(s).
documents.summary: This document provides instructions for importing existing SQLite databases into Cloudflare D1 and exporting D1 data to SQL files. It covers file conversion processes, Wrangler CLI commands, and troubleshooting common migration errors like statement length limits.

documents.title: Local development · Cloudflare D1 docs

documents.summary: This document explains how to develop and test Cloudflare D1 databases locally using Wrangler and Miniflare, covering local sessions, data persistence, and programmatic testing.

documents.title: Global read replication · Cloudflare D1 docs
documents.description: D1 read replication can lower latency for read queries and scale read throughput by adding read-only database copies, called read replicas, across regions globally closer to clients.
documents.summary: This document explains how to use Cloudflare D1 read replication and the Sessions API to improve read throughput and reduce latency by distributing database copies globally while maintaining sequential consistency.

documents.title: Alarms · Cloudflare Durable Objects docs
documents.description: Durable Objects alarms allow you to schedule the Durable Object to be woken up at a time in the future. When the alarm's scheduled time comes, the alarm() handler method will be called. Alarms are modified using the Storage API, and alarm operations follow the same rules as other storage operations.
documents.summary: This document explains how to use the Durable Objects Alarms API to schedule code execution, manage persistent alarms, and handle retries within Cloudflare Workers.

documents.title: Durable Object Base Class · Cloudflare Durable Objects docs
documents.description: The DurableObject base class is an abstract class which all Durable Objects inherit from. This base class provides a set of optional methods, frequently referred to as handler methods, which can respond to events, for example a webSocketMessage when using the WebSocket Hibernation API. To provide a concrete example, here is a Durable Object MyDurableObject which extends DurableObject and implements the fetch handler to return "Hello, World!" to the calling Worker.
documents.summary: This document defines the DurableObject base class and details its lifecycle methods and properties for handling HTTP requests, alarms, and WebSocket communications.

documents.title: Durable Object Container · Cloudflare Durable Objects docs
documents.description:
When using a Container-enabled Durable Object, you can access the Durable Object's associated container via
the container object which is on the ctx property. This allows you to start, stop, and interact with the container.
documents.summary: This document provides a technical reference for the container object in Container-enabled Durable Objects, covering lifecycle management, networking, and monitoring methods.

documents.title: Durable Object ID · Cloudflare Durable Objects docs
documents.description: A Durable Object ID is a 64-digit hexadecimal number used to identify a Durable Object. Not all 64-digit hex numbers are valid IDs. Durable Object IDs are constructed indirectly via the DurableObjectNamespace interface.
documents.summary: This document describes the DurableObjectId interface used to identify Cloudflare Durable Objects and explains its methods for string conversion, equality comparison, and name retrieval.

documents.title: KV-backed Durable Object Storage (Legacy) · Cloudflare Durable Objects docs
documents.description: The Durable Object Storage API allows Durable Objects to access transactional and strongly consistent storage. A Durable Object's attached storage is private to its unique instance and cannot be accessed by other objects.
documents.summary: This document provides a detailed reference for the Durable Object Storage API, focusing on the asynchronous key-value methods for legacy KV-backed and modern SQLite-backed instances. It explains how to access persistent, strongly consistent storage and use methods like get and put to manage object data.

documents.title: Durable Object Namespace · Cloudflare Durable Objects docs
documents.description: A Durable Object namespace is a set of Durable Objects that are backed by the same Durable Object class. There is only one Durable Object namespace per class. A Durable Object namespace can contain any number of Durable Objects.
documents.summary: This document explains the DurableObjectNamespace interface used in Cloudflare Workers to manage and access instances of Durable Objects. It details the methods available for generating object IDs and obtaining stubs to interact with stateful worker instances.

documents.title: SQLite-backed Durable Object Storage · Cloudflare Durable Objects docs
documents.description: The Durable Object Storage API allows Durable Objects to access transactional and strongly consistent storage. A Durable Object's attached storage is private to its unique instance and cannot be accessed by other objects.
documents.summary: This document details the storage API for SQLite-backed Durable Objects, providing methods for transactional, strongly consistent data access via SQL, key-value, and alarm interfaces. It explains how to interact with the embedded SQLite database and highlights the advantages over legacy KV-backed storage.

documents.title: Durable Object State · Cloudflare Durable Objects docs
documents.description: The DurableObjectState interface is accessible as an instance property on the Durable Object class. This interface encapsulates methods that modify the state of a Durable Object, for example which WebSockets are attached to a Durable Object or how the runtime should handle concurrent Durable Object requests.
documents.summary: This document explains the DurableObjectState interface, which provides methods for managing concurrency, handling WebSocket hibernation, and accessing storage within Cloudflare Durable Objects.

documents.title: Durable Object Stub · Cloudflare Durable Objects docs
documents.description: The DurableObjectStub interface is a client used to invoke methods on a remote Durable Object. The type of DurableObjectStub is generic to allow for RPC methods to be invoked on the stub.
documents.summary: This document describes the DurableObjectStub interface, which acts as a client for invoking methods on remote Durable Objects while ensuring message delivery order through E-order semantics.

documents.title: Error handling · Cloudflare Durable Objects docs
documents.description: Any uncaught exceptions thrown by a Durable Object or thrown by Durable Objects' infrastructure (such as overloads or network errors) will be propagated to the callsite of the client. Catching these exceptions allows you to retry creating the DurableObjectStub and sending requests.

You can have millions of them around the world. However, unlike regular Workers:

Hyperdrive maintains a pool of connections to your database. These are optimally placed to minimize the latency for your applications. You can configure

documents.title: Metrics · Cloudflare Pages docs
documents.description: Functions metrics can help you diagnose issues and understand your workloads by showing performance and usage data for your Functions.

It provides detailed definitions of various health metrics to help developers diagnose issues and monitor workload performance.

documents.title: Middleware · Cloudflare Pages docs
documents.description: Middleware is reusable logic that can be run before your onRequest function. Middlewares are typically utility functions. Error handling, user authentication, and logging are typical candidates for middleware within an application.
documents.summary: This document explains how to implement, scope, and chain middleware functions in Cloudflare Pages to handle logic like error reporting and authentication across multiple routes.

documents.title: Module support · Cloudflare Pages docs
documents.description: Pages Functions provide support for several module types, much like Workers. This means that you can import and use external modules such as WebAssembly (Wasm), text and binary files inside your Functions code.
documents.summary: This guide explains how to import and utilize various module types such as ECMAScript, WebAssembly, text, and binary files within Cloudflare Pages Functions.

documents.title: Pages Plugins · Cloudflare Pages docs
documents.description: Cloudflare maintains a number of official Pages Plugins for you to use in your Pages projects:
documents.summary: This document explains how to author and use Cloudflare Pages Plugins to add reusable routing and functionality to Pages projects. It covers the plugin development lifecycle, including project structure, middleware implementation, and TypeScript integration.

documents.title: Pricing · Cloudflare Pages docs
documents.description: Requests to your Functions are billed as Cloudflare Workers requests. Workers plans and pricing can be found in the Workers documentation.
documents.summary: This document outlines the pricing and billing structure for Cloudflare Pages Functions, explaining how requests are counted towards Workers plan quotas and distinguishing between static and dynamic requests.

documents.title: Routing · Cloudflare Pages docs
documents.description: Functions utilize file-based routing. Your /functions directory structure determines the designated routes that your Functions will run on. You can create a /functions directory with as many levels as needed for your project's use case. Review the following directory:
documents.summary: This document explains how to implement and configure routing for Cloudflare Pages Functions, covering file-based structures, dynamic path segments, and the use of the _routes.json configuration file.

documents.title: Smart Placement · Cloudflare Pages docs
documents.description: By default, Workers and Pages Functions are invoked in a data center closest to where the request was received. If you are running back-end logic in a Pages Function, it may be more performant to run that Pages Function closer to your back-end infrastructure rather than the end user. Smart Placement (beta) automatically places your workloads in an optimal location that minimizes latency and speeds up your applications.
documents.summary: This document explains how to use Cloudflare Pages Smart Placement to optimize performance by moving compute workloads closer to backend infrastructure. It provides instructions for enabling the feature via the dashboard and details technical considerations for middleware and asset fetching.

documents.title: Source maps and stack traces · Cloudflare Pages docs

documents.title: TypeScript · Cloudflare Pages docs

documents.title: Configuration · Cloudflare Pages docs

documents.title: Preview Local Projects with Cloudflare Tunnel · Cloudflare Pages docs

In practical terms, you can use Cloudflare Tunnel to allow remote access to services running on your local machine. It is an alternative to popular tools like Ngrok, and provides free, long-running tunnels via the TryCloudflare service.

documents.title: How Queues Works · Cloudflare Queues docs
documents.description: Cloudflare Queues is a flexible messaging queue that allows you to queue messages for asynchronous processing. Message queues are great at decoupling components of applications, like the checkout and order fulfillment services for an e-commerce site. Decoupled services are easier to reason about, deploy, and implement, allowing you to ship features that delight your customers without worrying about synchronizing complex deployments. Queues also allow you to batch and buffer calls to downstream services and APIs.
documents.summary: This document introduces the core concepts and architecture of Cloudflare Queues, explaining how producers and consumers facilitate asynchronous message processing. It details queue behavior, reliability standards, message content types, and the differences between push and pull consumers.

documents.title: Limits · Cloudflare R2 docs
documents.description:
1 Bucket management operations include creating, deleting, listing,
and configuring buckets. This limit does not apply to reading or writing objects to a bucket.

 2 The object size limit is 5 GiB less than 5 TiB, so 4.995
TiB.

 3 The max upload size is 5 MiB less than 5 GiB, so 4.995 GiB.

 4 Max upload size applies to uploading a file via one request,
uploading a part of a multipart upload, or copying into a part of a multipart
upload. If you have a Worker, its inbound request size is constrained by
Workers request limits. The max
upload size limit does not apply to subrequests.

 5 Concurrent writes  to the same object name (key) at a higher rate will cause you to see HTTP 429 (rate limited) responses, as you would with other object storage systems.

documents.title: Realtime vs Regular SFUs · Cloudflare Realtime docs

Realtime is designed for developers looking to integrate WebRTC functionalities in a server-client architecture without delving deep into the complexities of regional scaling or server management.

documents.title: What is TURN? · Cloudflare Realtime docs
documents.description: TURN (Traversal Using Relays around NAT) is a protocol that assists in traversing Network Address Translators (NATs) or firewalls in order to facilitate peer-to-peer communications. It is an extension of the STUN (Session Traversal Utilities for NAT) protocol and is defined in RFC 8656.
documents.summary: This document explains the TURN protocol, its role in NAT traversal for peer-to-peer communication, and the fundamental concepts and workflows required to use it in real-time applications.

manifest URL.

documents.title: Download video or audio · Cloudflare Stream docs
documents.description:
When you upload a video to Stream, it can be streamed using HLS/DASH. However, for certain use-cases, you may want to download the MP4 or M4A file.
For cases such as offline viewing, you may want to download the MP4 file. Whereas, for downstream tasks like AI summarization, if you want to extract only the audio, downloading an M4A file may be more useful.

documents.title: Secure your Stream · Cloudflare Stream docs
documents.description: By default, videos on Stream can be viewed by anyone with just a video id. If you want to make your video private by default and only give access to certain users, you can use the signed URL feature. When you mark a video to require signed URL, it can no longer be accessed publicly with only the video id. Instead, the user will need a signed url token to watch or download the video.

It details two methods for generating access tokens: using the built-in token endpoint for low-volume testing or using signing keys for high-volume production environments.

documents.title: Blocking Triggers · Cloudflare Zaraz docs
documents.description: Blocking Triggers are triggers that instead of being used to define when to start an action, are used to define when to not start an action. You may need to block one or more actions in a tool from firing when a specific condition arises. For these cases, you can set Blocking Triggers.
documents.summary: This document explains how to configure and use Blocking Triggers in Cloudflare Zaraz to prevent specific tool actions from executing under defined conditions.

documents.title: Context Enricher · Cloudflare Zaraz docs
documents.description: The Zaraz Context Enricher is a tool to modify or enrich the context that is being used across Zaraz using a Cloudflare Worker. The Context Enricher allows you access to the client and system variables.
documents.summary: This document explains how to use the Zaraz Context Enricher to modify or augment client and system context variables through Cloudflare Workers. It provides instructions for creating, configuring, and implementing custom logic to process and enrich Zaraz data before it is used.

documents.title: Data layer compatibility mode · Cloudflare Zaraz docs
documents.description: Cloudflare Zaraz offers backwards compatibility with the dataLayer function found in tag management software, used to track events and other parameters. This way you can keep your current implementation and Cloudflare Zaraz will automatically collect your events.
documents.summary: This document explains how to enable and use the dataLayer compatibility mode in Cloudflare Zaraz to automatically translate existing dataLayer events into zaraz.track calls.

documents.title: Use Zaraz on domains not proxied by Cloudflare · Cloudflare Zaraz docs
documents.description: You can load Zaraz on domains that are not proxied through Cloudflare. However, you will need to create a separate domain, or subdomain, proxied by Cloudflare (also known as orange-clouded domains), and load the script from it:
documents.summary: This document explains how to load Cloudflare Zaraz on domains that are not proxied by Cloudflare by routing the script through a separate proxied subdomain.

documents.title: Google Consent Mode · Cloudflare Zaraz docs
documents.description: Google Consent Mode is used by Google tools to manage consent regarding the usage of private data and Personally Identifiable Information (PII). Zaraz provides automatic support for Consent Mode v2, as well as manual support for Consent Mode v1.
documents.summary: This document provides instructions for implementing and managing Google Consent Mode versions 1 and 2 within Cloudflare Zaraz to handle user privacy preferences for Google tools.

documents.title: Configuration Import & Export · Cloudflare Zaraz docs
documents.description: Exporting your Zaraz configuration can be useful if you want to create a local backup or if you need to import it to another website. Zaraz provides an easy way to export and import your configuration.
documents.summary: This document provides step-by-step instructions on how to export and import Zaraz configurations using the Cloudflare dashboard for backups or site migrations.

documents.title: Custom Managed Components · Cloudflare Zaraz docs
documents.description: Zaraz supports loading custom third-party tools using Managed Components. These can be Managed Components that you have developed yourself or that were developed by others. Using Custom Managed Components with Zaraz is done by converting them into a Cloudflare Worker running in your account.
documents.summary: This document explains how to deploy and configure Custom Managed Components in Cloudflare Zaraz to run third-party tools as Cloudflare Workers. It provides instructions for preparing, deploying, and setting permissions for custom components within the Cloudflare ecosystem.

documents.title: Load Zaraz selectively · Cloudflare Zaraz docs
documents.description: You can use Configuration Rules to load Zaraz selectively on specific URLs or subdomains. Configuration Rules can also be used to block Zaraz from loading based on cookies, IP addresses or anything else related to a request.
documents.summary: This document explains how to use Cloudflare Configuration Rules to selectively load or block Zaraz on specific URLs, subdomains, or based on request parameters.

documents.title: Load Zaraz manually · Cloudflare Zaraz docs
documents.description: By default, if your domain is proxied by Cloudflare, Zaraz will automatically inject itself to HTML pages in your site. This makes it easier to get up and running quickly. However, you might want to load Zaraz manually, for example to test Zaraz on specific pages first.
documents.summary: This guide explains how to manually load the Zaraz script on Cloudflare-proxied websites by disabling auto-injection and adding a specific script tag to the HTML head.

documents.title: Send Zaraz logs to Logpush · Cloudflare Zaraz docs
documents.description: Send Zaraz logs to an external storage provider like R2 or S3.
documents.summary: This document provides instructions for configuring Cloudflare Logpush to export Zaraz event logs to external storage providers and defines the available log fields.

documents.title: Using JSONata · Cloudflare Zaraz docs
documents.description: For advanced use cases, it is sometimes useful to be able to retrieve a value in a particular way. For instance, you might be using zaraz.track to send a list of products to Zaraz, but the third-party tool you want to send this data to requires the total cost of the products. Alternatively, you may want to manipulate a value, such as converting it to lowercase.
documents.summary: This document explains how to use JSONata expressions within Cloudflare Zaraz to perform complex data operations, such as calculations and string manipulations, using the Zaraz Context.

documents.title: Consent API · Cloudflare Zaraz docs
documents.description: The Consent API allows you to programmatically control all aspects of the Consent Management program. This includes managing the modal, the consent status, and obtaining information about your configured purposes.
documents.summary: This document explains how to programmatically interact with the Zaraz Consent API to manage user consent preferences, modal visibility, and purpose configuration.

documents.title: Custom CSS · Cloudflare Zaraz docs

documents.title: IAB Transparency & Consent Framework Compliance · Cloudflare Zaraz docs
documents.description: The Zaraz Consent Management Platform is compliant with the IAB Transparency & Consent Framework. Enabling this feature could be required in order to serve Google Ads in the EEA and the UK.
documents.summary: This document explains how to enable and configure IAB Transparency & Consent Framework compliance within the Zaraz Consent Management Platform to meet regulatory requirements.

documents.title: Additional fields · Cloudflare Zaraz docs

documents.title: Create an action · Cloudflare Zaraz docs
documents.description: Once you have your triggers ready, you can use them to configure your actions. An action defines a specific task that your tool will perform.
documents.summary: This document provides step-by-step instructions for creating and configuring actions within Cloudflare Zaraz to perform specific tasks based on predefined triggers.

documents.title: Create a trigger · Cloudflare Zaraz docs
documents.description: Triggers define the conditions under which a tool will start an action. Since a tool must have actions in order to work, and actions must have triggers, it is important to set up your website's triggers correctly. A trigger can be made out of one or more Rules. Zaraz supports multiple types of Trigger Rules.
documents.summary: This document provides step-by-step instructions for creating and configuring triggers in Cloudflare Zaraz to control tool actions. It explains how to define rules using variables and match operations to ensure tools execute under specific website conditions.

documents.title: Edit tools and actions · Cloudflare Zaraz docs
documents.description: On this page you will be able to edit settings related to the tool, add actions, and edit existing ones. To edit an existing action, select its name.
documents.summary: This document provides step-by-step instructions for managing third-party tools and actions within the Cloudflare dashboard's Tag setup section.

documents.title: Edit a trigger · Cloudflare Zaraz docs
documents.description: You can edit every field related to the trigger, as well as add new trigger rules.
documents.summary: This document provides step-by-step instructions for editing and deleting triggers within Cloudflare's Tag setup and tool configuration settings.

documents.title: Preview changes before publishing · Cloudflare Zaraz docs
documents.description: Zaraz allows you to test your configurations before publishing them. This is helpful to avoid unintended consequences when deploying a new tool or trigger.
documents.summary: This document explains how to enable and use the Preview & Publish workflow in Cloudflare Zaraz to test configuration changes before they go live. It provides step-by-step instructions for activating preview mode, testing with a debug key, and publishing or reverting changes.

documents.title: Versions · Cloudflare Zaraz docs
documents.description: Version History enables you to keep track of all the Zaraz configuration changes made in your website. With Version History you can also revert changes to previous settings should there be a problem.
documents.summary: This document explains how to track, manage, and revert configuration changes in Cloudflare Zaraz using the Version History feature.

documents.title: Monitoring API · Cloudflare Zaraz docs
documents.description: The Zaraz Monitoring API allows users to retrieve detailed data on Zaraz events through the GraphQL Analytics API. Using this API, you can monitor events, pageviews, triggers, actions, and server-side request statuses, including any errors and successes. The data available through the API mirrors what is shown on the Zaraz Monitoring page in the dashboard, but with the API, you can query it programmatically to create alerts and notifications for unexpected deviations.
documents.summary: This document explains how to use the Zaraz Monitoring API via the GraphQL Analytics API to programmatically retrieve and monitor data for events, triggers, and server-side actions.

documents.title: Zaraz Context · Cloudflare Zaraz docs
documents.description: The Zaraz Context is a versatile object that provides a set of configurable properties for Zaraz, a web analytics tool for tracking user behavior on websites. These properties can be accessed and utilized across various components, including Worker Variables and JSONata expressions.
documents.summary: This document defines the Zaraz Context object and provides a detailed list of system and event properties available for tracking user behavior and device information. It explains how to access data such as page details, cookies, device specifications, and consent status within the Zaraz environment.

documents.title: Properties reference · Cloudflare Zaraz docs
documents.description: Cloudflare Zaraz offers properties that you can use when configuring the product. They are helpful to send data to a third-party tool or to create triggers as they have context about a specific user's browser session and the actions they take on the website. Below is a list of the properties you can access from the Cloudflare dashboard and their values.
documents.summary: This document provides a comprehensive reference of properties available in Cloudflare Zaraz for configuring third-party tools and triggers using session and browser data.

documents.title: Triggers and rules · Cloudflare Zaraz docs
documents.description: Triggers define the conditions under which a tool will start an action. In most cases, your objective will be to create triggers that match specific website events that are relevant to your business. A trigger can be based on an event that happened on your website, like after selecting a button or loading a specific page.
documents.summary: This document explains how to configure Cloudflare Zaraz triggers to initiate actions based on specific website events and browser-side interactions. It covers various rule types such as match rules, click listeners, element visibility, and timers for capturing user behavior.

documents.title: Create a variable · Cloudflare Zaraz docs
documents.description: Variables are reusable blocks of information. They allow you to have one source of data you can reuse across tools and triggers in the dashboard. You can then update this data in a single place.
documents.summary: This document explains how to create and manage reusable variables in Cloudflare Zaraz to streamline data updates across tools and triggers. It covers the different variable types available, including string, masked, and worker variables.

documents.title: Edit a variable · Cloudflare Zaraz docs
documents.description: [Go to **Tag setup**](https://dash.cloudflare.com/?to=/:account/tag-management/zaraz)
documents.summary: This document provides step-by-step instructions for managing variables in Cloudflare Zaraz, specifically how to edit existing variables and the requirements for deleting them.

documents.title: Worker Variables · Cloudflare Zaraz docs
documents.description: Zaraz Worker Variables are a powerful type of variable that you can configure and then use in your actions and triggers. Unlike string and masked variables, Worker Variables are dynamic. This means you can use a Cloudflare Worker to determine the value of the variable, allowing you to use them for countless purposes. For example:
documents.summary: This document explains how to create, configure, and implement Zaraz Worker Variables to generate dynamic values for actions and triggers using Cloudflare Workers and the Zaraz Context.

documents.title: Debug mode · Cloudflare Zaraz docs
documents.description:
Zaraz offers a debug mode to troubleshoot the events and triggers systems. To activate debug mode you need to create a special debug cookie (zarazDebug) containing your debug key.
You can set this cookie manually or via the zaraz.debug helper function available in your console.
documents.summary: This document explains how to activate and use Zaraz's debug mode to troubleshoot event and trigger systems using a debug key and a browser console command.

documents.title: Argo Smart Routing for SaaS · Cloudflare for Platforms docs
documents.description: Argo Smart Routing uses real-time global network information to route traffic on the fastest possible path across the Internet. Regardless of geographic location, this allows Cloudflare to optimize routing to make it faster, more reliable, and more secure. As a SaaS provider, you may want to emphasize the quickest traffic delivery for your end customers. To do so, enable Argo Smart Routing.
documents.summary: This document explains how Argo Smart Routing utilizes real-time global network data to optimize traffic delivery for improved speed, reliability, and security.

documents.title: Cache for SaaS · Cloudflare for Platforms docs
documents.description: Cloudflare makes customer websites faster by storing a copy of the website’s content on the servers of our globally distributed data centers. Content can be either static or dynamic: static content is “cacheable” or eligible for caching, and dynamic content is “uncacheable” or ineligible for caching. The cached copies of content are stored physically closer to users, optimized to be fast, and do not require recomputing.
documents.summary: Explains how Cloudflare improves website performance for SaaS providers by caching static and dynamic content across globally distributed data centers.

documents.title: Early Hints for SaaS · Cloudflare for Platforms docs
documents.description: Early Hints allows the browser to begin loading resources while the origin server is compiling the full response. This improves webpage’s loading speed for the end user. As a SaaS provider, you may prioritize speed for some of your custom hostnames. Using custom metadata, you can enable Early Hints per custom hostname.
documents.summary: This document explains how to enable Early Hints for Cloudflare for SaaS custom hostnames using the API to improve loading speeds for end users.

documents.title: How Orange-to-Orange (O2O) works · Cloudflare for Platforms docs
documents.description: Orange-to-Orange (O2O) is a specific traffic routing configuration where traffic routes through two Cloudflare zones: the first Cloudflare zone is owned by customer 1 and the second Cloudflare zone is owned by customer 2, who is considered a SaaS provider.
documents.summary: This document explains Orange-to-Orange (O2O) traffic routing, which occurs when traffic passes through a customer-owned Cloudflare zone before reaching a SaaS provider's Cloudflare zone. It details the prerequisites and traffic flow behavior for this specific configuration.

documents.title: Product compatibility · Cloudflare for Platforms docs
documents.description: As a general rule, settings on the customer zone will override settings on the SaaS zone. In addition, Orange-to-Orange does not permit traffic directed to a custom hostname zone into another custom hostname zone.
documents.summary: This document outlines product compatibility and configuration precedence rules between customer zones and SaaS provider zones in Cloudflare for SaaS (Orange-to-Orange) environments.

documents.title: Custom limits · Cloudflare for Platforms docs
documents.description: Custom limits allow you to programmatically enforce limits on your customers' Workers' resource usage. You can set limits for the maximum CPU time and number of subrequests per invocation. If a user Worker hits either of these limits, the user Worker will immediately throw an exception.
documents.summary: This document explains how to programmatically set and enforce resource usage limits, specifically CPU time and subrequests, for Workers using dynamic dispatch.

documents.title: Dynamic dispatch Worker · Cloudflare for Platforms docs
documents.description: A dynamic dispatch Worker is a specialized routing Worker that directs incoming requests to the appropriate user Workers in your dispatch namespace. Instead of using Workers Routes, dispatch Workers let you programmatically control request routing through code.
documents.summary: Explains how to use and configure dynamic dispatch Workers to programmatically route requests to user Workers within a dispatch namespace.

documents.title: Hostname routing · Cloudflare for Platforms docs
documents.description: Learn how to route requests to the dispatch worker.
documents.summary: This document explains how to use dynamic dispatch Workers to efficiently route traffic for millions of vanity domains and subdomains while bypassing traditional route limits.

documents.title: Observability · Cloudflare for Platforms docs
documents.description: Workers for Platforms provides you with logs and analytics that can be used to share data with end users.
documents.summary: This document explains how to access and manage execution logs and performance analytics for Workers for Platforms using tools like Logpush, Tail Workers, and the GraphQL Analytics API.

documents.title: Outbound Workers · Cloudflare for Platforms docs
documents.description: Outbound Workers sit between your customer's Workers and the public Internet. They give you visibility into all outgoing fetch() requests from user Workers.
documents.summary: This document explains how to use Outbound Workers to intercept, log, and modify outgoing subrequests from user Workers within a dispatch namespace. It provides instructions for configuration in Wrangler and code examples for implementing request interception and authentication.

documents.title: Static assets · Cloudflare for Platforms docs
documents.description: Host static assets on Cloudflare's global network and deliver faster load times worldwide with Workers for Platforms.
documents.summary: This document explains how to deploy static assets to User Workers using Workers for Platforms, covering the workflow for creating upload sessions and transmitting file contents via API.

documents.title: Tags · Cloudflare for Platforms docs
documents.description: Use tags to organize, search, and filter user Workers at scale. Tag Workers based on customer ID, plan type, project ID, or environment. After you tag user Workers, you can perform bulk operations like deleting all Workers for a specific customer.
documents.summary: This document explains how to use tags to organize and manage user Workers at scale, including instructions for the Cloudflare dashboard and a complete REST API reference.

documents.title: Local development · Cloudflare for Platforms docs

documents.title: Worker Isolation · Cloudflare for Platforms docs
documents.description: By default, Workers inside of a dispatch namespace are considered "untrusted." This provides the strongest isolation between Workers and is best in cases where your customers have control over the code that's being deployed.

documents.title: S3 API compatibility · Cloudflare R2 docs
documents.description:
R2 implements the S3 API to allow users and their applications to migrate with ease. When comparing to AWS S3, Cloudflare has removed some API operations' features and added others. The S3 API operations are listed below with their current implementation status. Feature implementation is currently in progress. Refer back to this page for updates.
The API is available via the https://<ACCOUNT_ID>.r2.cloudflarestorage.com endpoint. Find your account ID in the Cloudflare dashboard.
documents.summary: This document provides a detailed compatibility reference for Cloudflare R2's implementation of the S3 API, outlining supported bucket and object operations.

documents.title: Extensions · Cloudflare R2 docs
documents.description: R2 implements some extensions on top of the basic S3 API. This page outlines these additional, available features. Some of the functionality described in this page requires setting a custom header. For examples on how to do so, refer to Configure custom headers.
documents.summary: This document details Cloudflare R2's extensions to the standard S3 API, covering Unicode metadata handling, automatic bucket creation, and enhanced object listing and copying capabilities.

documents.title: Presigned URLs · Cloudflare R2 docs
documents.description: Presigned URLs are an S3 concept for granting temporary access to objects without exposing your API credentials. A presigned URL includes signature parameters in the URL itself, authorizing anyone with the URL to perform a specific operation (like GetObject or PutObject) on a specific object until the URL expires.
documents.summary: This document explains how to generate and use presigned URLs to grant temporary, secure access to Cloudflare R2 objects for operations like reading, writing, and deleting. It provides implementation examples using various SDKs and outlines best practices for limiting access via expiry and content types.

documents.title: Workers API reference · Cloudflare R2 docs
documents.description: The in-Worker R2 API is accessed by binding an R2 bucket to a Worker. The Worker you write can expose external access to buckets via a route or manipulate R2 objects internally.
documents.summary: This document explains how to use the in-Worker R2 API to interact with R2 buckets through bindings and perform operations like object manipulation and retrieval. It provides definitions for bucket methods and the R2Object structure used to manage storage within Cloudflare Workers.

documents.title: Use R2 from Workers · Cloudflare R2 docs
documents.description: C3 (create-cloudflare-cli) is a command-line tool designed to help you set up and deploy Workers & Pages applications to Cloudflare as fast as possible.
documents.summary: This document guides users through creating a Cloudflare Worker and integrating it with an R2 bucket for object storage. It explains how to set up the environment, bind resources, and perform basic CRUD operations within the Worker.

documents.title: Use the R2 multipart API from Workers · Cloudflare R2 docs
documents.description:
By following this guide, you will create a Worker through which your applications can perform multipart uploads.
This example worker could serve as a basis for your own use case where you can add authentication to the worker, or even add extra validation logic when uploading each part.
This guide also contains an example Python application that uploads files to this worker.
documents.summary: This guide explains how to implement a Cloudflare Worker that interfaces with the R2 multipart upload API to facilitate large file uploads through custom endpoints.

For some functionality you may want to set a request header on an entire category of requests. Other times you may want to configure a different header for each individual request. documents.title: Summary · Cloudflare Realtime docs
documents.description: RealtimeKit generates AI-powered meeting summaries from transcript data.
documents.summary: This document explains how to enable, configure, and retrieve AI-generated meeting summaries from transcript data using RealtimeKit's API and webhook integration.

documents.title: Transcription · Cloudflare Realtime docs
documents.description: RealtimeKit provides two transcription modes powered by Cloudflare Workers AI:
documents.summary: This document explains how to implement and configure real-time and post-meeting transcription services within RealtimeKit using Cloudflare Workers AI models.

documents.title: Meeting · Cloudflare Realtime docs
documents.description: Meeting is a re-usable virtual room that you can join and interact in, in real-time.
documents.summary: This document explains the core concepts of Meetings and Sessions in RealtimeKit, detailing the lifecycle of virtual rooms, participant management features like waiting rooms and stages, and how to create meetings via API.

documents.title: Participant · Cloudflare Realtime docs
documents.description:
Before a user can join a meeting through the RealtimeKit SDK, your backend must add that user as a participant to that meeting using the Add Participant API.
In RealtimeKit, a participant represents a user who is allowed to join a specific meeting.
documents.summary: This document explains the concept of participants in RealtimeKit, detailing how to add them to meetings, manage authentication tokens, and use custom identifiers for user mapping.

documents.title: Preset · Cloudflare Realtime docs
documents.description:
A Preset is a re-usable configuration that defines a participant’s experience in a Meeting.
It determines:
documents.summary: This document defines Presets in RealtimeKit as reusable configurations that control participant roles, permissions, and UI experiences within a meeting. It outlines various permission categories such as host controls, stage management, and chat, while providing instructions on creating presets via the dashboard or API.

documents.title: Session Lifecycle · Cloudflare Realtime docs
documents.description:
The Session Guide explains what a session is and how to initialize one.
In this guide we will talk about what happens to a peer as they move through a session, when do they go to the setup screen, waitlist screen, ended screen or any other screen, and how you can hook into these events to perform custom actions.
documents.summary: This document explains the lifecycle of a peer within a session, detailing the transitions between setup, waitlist, meeting, and ended screens.

documents.title: Breakout Rooms · Cloudflare Realtime docs
documents.description: Breakout rooms allow participants of a meeting to split into smaller groups for targeted discussions and collaboration. With the rise of remote work and online learning, breakout rooms have become an essential tool for enhancing engagement and building community in virtual settings. They are an ideal choice for workshops, online classrooms, or when you need to speak privately with select participants outside the main meeting.
documents.summary: This document provides a comprehensive guide to implementing and managing breakout rooms in RealtimeKit, detailing participant roles, permission configurations, and the use of SDK APIs for meeting orchestration.

documents.title: Chat · Cloudflare Realtime docs
documents.description: This guide explains how to send and receive chat messages in a meeting using Cloudflare RealtimeKit.
documents.summary: This guide explains how to implement and manage chat functionality using Cloudflare RealtimeKit, covering message operations and programmatic data export via the Chat Replay API.

documents.title: Display active speakers · Cloudflare Realtime docs
documents.description: RealtimeKit automatically detects and tracks participants who are actively speaking in a meeting. You can display either a single active speaker or multiple active speakers in your application UI, depending on your design requirements.
documents.summary: This document explains how RealtimeKit tracks and manages active speakers in a meeting, allowing developers to identify and display participants with prominent audio activity.

documents.title: End a session · Cloudflare Realtime docs
documents.description: To end the current session for all participants, remove all participants using kickAll(). This stops any ongoing recording for that session and sets the session status to ENDED.
documents.summary: This document explains how to end a Cloudflare RealtimeKit session by removing all participants and provides instructions for permanently disabling a meeting via backend APIs.

documents.title: Error Codes · Cloudflare Realtime docs

documents.title: Manage Participants in a Session · Cloudflare Realtime docs
documents.description:
Use RealtimeKit host controls to manage other participants in a live session. You can mute audio or video, pin a participant, or remove participants from the session.
These actions require specific host control permissions enabled in the local participant's Preset.
Before you show UI controls or call these methods, verify that the local participant has the necessary permissions.
In this guide, the local participant refers to the user performing the actions.
documents.summary: This document explains how to use RealtimeKit host controls to manage session participants through actions such as muting audio, disabling video, pinning users, and removing participants.

documents.summary: This guide explains the different methods for acquiring and managing participant audio and video tracks within the RealtimeKit SDK, covering both automatic and manual approaches.

documents.title: Custom Domains · Cloudflare Workers docs
documents.description: Custom Domains allow you to connect your Worker to a domain or subdomain, without having to make changes to your DNS settings or perform any certificate management. Unlike Routes, Custom Domains point all paths of a domain or subdomain to your Worker.

documents.title: 📅 Compatibility Dates · Cloudflare Workers docs
documents.description:
Miniflare uses compatibility dates to opt-into backwards-incompatible changes
from a specific date. If one isn't set, it will default to some time far in the
past.
documents.summary: This document explains how to use compatibility dates and flags in Miniflare to manage backwards-incompatible changes and specific runtime behaviors.

documents.title: 📨 Fetch Events · Cloudflare Workers docs
documents.description:
Whenever an HTTP request is made, a Request object is dispatched to your worker, then the generated Response is returned. The
Request object will include a
cf object.
Miniflare will log the method, path, status, and the time it took to respond.
documents.summary: This document explains how to handle HTTP requests in Miniflare, including dispatching fetch events for testing and configuring upstream response behavior.

scheduled events are automatically dispatched according to the specified cron
triggers:

documents.title: 🕸 Web Standards · Cloudflare Workers docs
documents.description:
When using the API, Miniflare allows you to substitute custom Responses for
fetch() calls using undici's
MockAgent API.
This is useful for testing Workers that make HTTP requests to other services. To
enable fetch mocking, create a
MockAgent
using the createFetchMock() function, then set this using the fetchMock
option.
documents.summary: This document explains how to mock outbound fetch requests in Miniflare using the MockAgent API and createFetchMock function to facilitate testing of Workers that interact with external services.

documents.description:
Miniflare will always upgrade Web Socket connections. The Worker must respond
with a status 101 Switching Protocols response including a webSocket. For
example, the Worker below implements an echo WebSocket server:
documents.summary: This document explains how to implement and handle WebSocket connections in Miniflare, covering both server-side Worker logic and client-side dispatching.

documents.title: 🐛 Attaching a Debugger · Cloudflare Workers docs
documents.description:
You can use regular Node.js tools to debug your Workers. Setting breakpoints,
watching values and inspecting the call stack are all examples of things you can
do with a debugger.
documents.summary: This document provides instructions for setting up breakpoint debugging in Cloudflare Workers using Miniflare with IDEs like Visual Studio Code and WebStorm.

documents.title: ⚡️ Live Reload · Cloudflare Workers docs

changes when liveReload is set to true.

documents.title: ⬆️ Migrating from Version 2 · Cloudflare Workers docs
documents.description:
Miniflare v3 now uses workerd, the
open-source Cloudflare Workers runtime. This is the same runtime that's deployed
on Cloudflare's network, giving bug-for-bug compatibility and practically
eliminating behavior mismatches. Refer to the
Miniflare v3 and
Wrangler v3 announcements for more
information.
documents.summary: This document outlines the migration path from Miniflare v2 to v3, detailing the transition to the workerd runtime, the removal of the standalone CLI, and specific breaking changes in the API.

documents.title: Authentication · Cloudflare Workers docs
documents.description: In Cloudflare’s system, a user can have multiple accounts and zones. As a result, your user is configured globally on your machine via a single Cloudflare Token. Your account(s) and zone(s) will be configured per project, but will use your Cloudflare Token to authenticate all API calls. A configuration file is created in a .wrangler directory in your computer’s home directory.
documents.summary: This document provides instructions for authenticating and configuring Wrangler v1 with Cloudflare using CLI commands, environment variables, and API tokens.

documents.description: Occasionally, a domain will be flagged as “high risk” by Cloudflare’s CA partners. Typically this is done only for domains with an Alexa ranking of 1-1,000 and domains that have been flagged for phishing or malware by Google’s Safe Browsing service.
documents.summary: This document provides troubleshooting and configuration guidance for resolving SSL certificate issuance issues related to high-risk domains, CAA record conflicts, and validation timeouts.
